grasses.name: golden hakonechloa
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted garden compost into the planting hole. Leave flower heads to dry out through the winter, adding valuable texture to plantings.  Apply a light mulch (3cm) of well-rotted garden compost after cutting back old foliage and before new growth emerges in spring.

grasses.name: switch grass
grasses.care: Garden care: Lift and divide congested colonies between mid-spring and summer

grasses.name: Chinese silver grass
grasses.soil: Soil: fertile, moist, well drained or sandy
grasses.care: Garden care: Cut down to the ground in late winter before the new foliage appears.

grasses.name: hakonechloa
grasses.position: Position: prefers a cool, moist environment in sun or part shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted garden compost into the planting hold.  Leave flower heads to dry out through the winter, adding valuable texture to plantings.  Apply a light mulch (3cm) of well-rotted garden compost after cutting back old foliage and before new growth emerges in spring.

grasses.name: sedge
grasses.position: Position:   full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Comb through the plant in winter to remove dead foliage. Feed with a general purpose fertiliser during  the growing season and if necessary, lift and divide over-large clumps in early  spring.

grasses.name: silver grass
grasses.soil: Soil:  fertile, moist, well drained or sandy
grasses.care: Garden care:   Protect from excessive winter wet. Cut down to the ground in late winter, before new foliage appears.

grasses.name: feather reed grass
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.soil: Soil: dry or wet, well-drained soil
grasses.flowering: Flowering period: early summer to autumn
grasses.care: Garden care: Very low maintenance, it simply needs to be cut down to the ground in February. Don�t be tempted to chop it earlier, as its wheat-coloured stems add drama and strong winter presence to the garden.

grasses.name: tufted hair grass
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.soil: Soil: dry to moist, neutral to acid soil
grasses.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
grasses.care: Garden care: Remove the faded flower-heads in late winter before new growth appears. If the foliage has also started to look tatty at that time of the year, then this too can be cut back hard. In warm areas the plant has a tendency to self-seed freely. Where this is the case remove unwanted seedlings as part of routine border maintenance.

grasses.name: Japanese rush
grasses.soil: Soil: pool margins or very moist soil
grasses.care: Other features: beautiful grass-like, golden yellow leaves

grasses.name: fountain grass
grasses.care: Garden care: A generous layer of mulch in autumn will help keep the roots warmer in winter. Prune back the previous years growth each spring.

grasses.care: Garden care: Incorporate lots of well-rotted garden compost into the planting hole.  Leave flower heads to dry out through the winter, adding valuable texture to plantings.  Apply a light mulch (3cm) of well-rotted garden compost after cutting back old foliage and before new growth emerges in spring.

grasses.name: sedge
grasses.position: Position:   full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Comb through the plant in winter with your fingers to remove dead foliage and snip out any leaves in summer.

grasses.name: ficinia
grasses.soil: Soil: moist, moderately fertile, slightly acidic soil
grasses.care: Garden care: Keep well watered, particularly during the warmer  months, and protect plants from frost. In colder regions, it's best kept in a pot so it can be moved to a sheltered spot during the winter.

grasses.name: snowy woodrush
grasses.soil: Soil:  poor to moderately-fertile,humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil
grasses.care: Garden care:  Lift and divide congested colonies between April and June.  Remove tatty foliage in early spring.

grasses.name: Wisley Piet Oudolf Border Collection
grasses.soil: Soil: light, moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well- drained soil
grasses.care: Sanguisorba officinalis 'Red Thunder':  One of Piet Oudolf's favourites. In spring the deciduous feathery, green foliage  emerges and forms attractive groundcover, but it is the summer when the  unusual red flowers top the slender, upright sems that it really becomes a head-turner. Perfect for prairie style planting schemes, as it looks righ at   home swaying sea of grasses. bees. Grows to 1.2m.

grasses.name: blue oat grass
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.soil: Soil: well-drained, poor to moderately fertile, preferably alkaline soil
grasses.care: Garden care:  Remove dead foliage and flowering stems in late winter or early spring.

grasses.name: Hakonechloa collection
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Hakonechloa macra:Slowly spreading to form a generous clump of arching linear green leaves, the soft form of this grass looks wonderful when teamed with plants that have a striking silhouette. The flowerheads create a frothy effect amongst the foliage in late summer. Height to 35cm.

grasses.name: silver grass
grasses.care: Garden care: Leave top growth standing through winter. Cut back to ground level late February as new shoots appear within the crown.

grasses.name: tufted hair grass  (syn. Golden Dew)
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.soil: Soil: dry to moist, neutral to acid soil
grasses.growth: Rate of growth: average to fast-growing
grasses.care: Garden care: Remove the faded flower-heads in late winter before new growth appears. If the foliage has also started to look tatty at that time of the year, then this too can be cut back hard. In warm areas the plant has a tendency to self-seed freely. Where this is the case remove unwanted seedlings as part of routine border maintenance.

grasses.name: pampas grass
grasses.care: Garden care: Protect the crowns of young plants during the first winter with a deep, dry mulch. Each year in late-winter or early-spring wearing stout gardening gloves remove the previous year's stems by cutting and combing. Make sure you do wear stout gardening gloves when you are working with these plants as the leaves have sharp margins which can cut your hands.

grasses.name: Japanese blood grass (syn Imperata Red Baron )
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Cut down to the ground in February.  In cold areas, protect the roots by mulching with straw or well-rotted compost.  If you are growing it in a container, keep it well watered.

grasses.name: blue fescue
grasses.care: Garden care:   Comb through the plant with your fingers in winter to remove dead foliage.  Container-grown specimens should be watered well when they are establishing.  Plants need replacing every few years as they become tatty-looking.

grasses.name: Bowles' golden sedge
grasses.position: Position: full sun or partial shade
grasses.soil: Soil: fertile, moist or wet soil
grasses.care: Garden care: These plants are potted up (using a suitable aquatic compost) into 1-litre aquatic pots. These pots are made of a fine mesh, which allows water to circulate through the compost, providing the plants with both oxygen and nutrients. If you are using them as a aquatic plant, they can be placed straight into the pond, however they will preform better if planted out sooner rather than later. To enhance flowering divide congested clumps every three to five years.

grasses.name: sedge
grasses.position: Position:   full sun or partial shade
grasses.care: Garden care: Comb through the plant in late winter to remove any dead foliage. Feed with a general purpose fertiliser  during the growing season and if necessary, lift and divide over-large  clumps in early spring.
